title: 110_hr3148
content: The "Child Pornography Elimination Act of 2007" mandates a minimum sentence of 2 to 15 years for possession of child pornography. Section 13032 of Title 42 is strengthened to ensure effective reporting of child pornography. Section 227(b)(2) of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to impose fines on providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services who knowingly or negligently fail to report child abuse, with fines ranging from $150,000 to $300,000 for repeated failures. Providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services who negligently fail to report child abuse may face civil penalties imposed by the Federal Communications Commission. The penalties range from $50,000 for an initial failure to report to $100,000 for any subsequent failures. The FCC has the authority to levy these penalties and will establish regulations in consultation with the Attorney General for enforcement and administrative review. SEC. 4 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include knowingly accessing child pornography with intent to view. SEC. 5 introduces a conspiracy provision for Chapter 77 offenses. SEC. 5 introduces a conspiracy provision for Chapter 77 offenses, amending Section 1594(a) of title 18, United States Code to include conspiring to commit offenses. SEC. 6 mandates restitution for certain child sex offenses. Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory restitution for offenses. The court must order the defendant to pay the victim's losses determined by the court, enforced similarly to other restitution orders. The term 'full amount of the victim's losses' includes costs for medical services, therapy, transportation, lost income, attorney's fees, and other losses resulting from the offense. The issuance of a restitution order under this section is mandatory and cannot be declined based on the defendant's economic circumstances or the victim's compensation from other sources. The term 'victim' refers to individuals harmed by a crime, including minors or incapacitated individuals. The legal guardian or representative of a victim who is a minor, incompetent, incapacitated, or deceased can be appointed by the court, but the defendant cannot be named as such representative or guardian. SEC. 7 amends the definition of illicit sexual conduct to include the production of child pornography. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute by amending various sections of title 18, United States Code to include section 1591. This includes amendments related to sexual exploitation, pornography, repeat offenders, release and detention, and administrative subpoenas.
